title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Tidyomics project
An open, open-source project spanning multiple R packages, and developers from around the world. Operates within the Bioconductor Project, with separate funding and organization. Coordination of development via GitHub Projects.

https://github.com/tidyomics
Announcement paper
tidiness_in_bioc channel in Bioconductor Slack

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text: Diagram of tidyomics workflows

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text: International development team

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Keep data organized in objects

We typically have more information than just a matrix
Row and column information (on features and samples)
Annotated matrix data, i.e. python’s xarray, AnnData
Metadata: organism, genome build, annotation release
2002: ExpressionSet; 2011: SummarizedExperiment
Endomorphic functions: x |> f -> x

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
SummarizedExperiment, “SE”
A SummarizedExperiment is annotated matrix data.
Imagine a matrix of counts:

counts <- matrix(
  rpois(16, lambda=100), ncol=4,
  dimnames=list(c("g1","g2","g3","g4"),
                c("s1","s2","s3","s4"))
)
counts

    s1  s2  s3  s4
g1  94 117 112  94
g2 111 104 103 112
g3  83  87 104 108
g4 101  82 101  99

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Row data


DataFrame with 4 rows and 2 columns
           id      symbol
  <character> <character>
1          g1         ABC
2          g2         DEF
3          g3         GHI
4          g4         JKL

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Column data


DataFrame with 4 rows and 3 columns
       sample   condition         sex
  <character> <character> <character>
1          s1           x           m
2          s2           y           m
3          s3           x           f
4          s4           y           f

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Assembled object

se <- SummarizedExperiment(
  assays = list(counts = counts),
  rowData = genes, 
  colData = samples,
  metadata = list(organism="Hsapiens")
  )
se

class: SummarizedExperiment 
dim: 4 4 
metadata(1): organism
assays(1): counts
rownames(4): g1 g2 g3 g4
rowData names(2): id symbol
colnames(4): s1 s2 s3 s4
colData names(3): sample condition sex

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Deals with bookkeeping issues
Reordering samples (columns) is a global operation:

se2 <- se[,c(1,3,2,4)]
assay(se2, "counts")

    s1  s3  s2  s4
g1  94 112 117  94
g2 111 103 104 112
g3  83 104  87 108
g4 101 101  82  99

colData(se2)

DataFrame with 4 rows and 3 columns
        sample   condition         sex
   <character> <character> <character>
s1          s1           x           m
s3          s3           x           f
s2          s2           y           m
s4          s4           y           f

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Deals with bookkeeping issues
Assignment that might result in sample swap results in an error:

assay(se2) <- counts
# Error:
# please use 'assay(x, withDimnames=FALSE)) <- value' or 
# 'assays(x, withDimnames=FALSE)) <- value'
# when the rownames or colnames of the supplied assay(s) are not 
# identical to those of the receiving  SummarizedExperiment object 'x'


Other such validity checks include comparison of genomic ranges across different genome builds.
Will result in an error.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
section: Can be a lot for new users
text:
Can be a lot for new users


[1] "colData"         "assays"          "NAMES"           "elementMetadata" "metadata"       


 [1] "!=,ANY,Vector-method"                                        
 [2] "!=,Vector,ANY-method"                                        
 [3] "!=,Vector,Vector-method"                                     
 [4] "[,SummarizedExperiment,ANY,ANY,ANY-method"                   
 [5] "[[,SummarizedExperiment,ANY,missing-method"                  
 [6] "[[<-,SummarizedExperiment,ANY,missing-method"                
 [7] "[<-,SummarizedExperiment,ANY,ANY,SummarizedExperiment-method"
 [8] "[<-,Vector,ANY,ANY,ANY-method"                               
 [9] "%in%,ANY,Vector-method"                                      
[10] "%in%,Vector,ANY-method"                                      


So while an advanced R/Bioconductor user should learn these methods, maybe not needed to immediately explore or visualize data, make basic data summaries.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Beginners know dplyr & ggplot2

library(dplyr)
# filter to samples in condition 'x'
samples |> 
  as_tibble() |> 
  filter(condition == "x")

# A tibble: 2 × 3
  sample condition sex  
  <chr>  <chr>     <chr>
1 s1     x         m    
2 s3     x         f

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Enabling dplyr verbs for omics

library(tidySummarizedExperiment)
se

# A SummarizedExperiment-tibble abstraction: 16 × 8
# Features=4 | Samples=4 | Assays=counts
   .feature .sample counts sample condition sex   id    symbol
   <chr>    <chr>    <int> <chr>  <chr>     <chr> <chr> <chr> 
 1 g1       s1          94 s1     x         m     g1    ABC   
 2 g2       s1         111 s1     x         m     g2    DEF   
 3 g3       s1          83 s1     x         m     g3    GHI   
 4 g4       s1         101 s1     x         m     g4    JKL   
 5 g1       s2         117 s2     y         m     g1    ABC   
 6 g2       s2         104 s2     y         m     g2    DEF   
 7 g3       s2          87 s2     y         m     g3    GHI   
 8 g4       s2          82 s2     y         m     g4    JKL   
 9 g1       s3         112 s3     x         f     g1    ABC   
10 g2       s3         103 s3     x         f     g2    DEF   
11 g3       s3         104 s3     x         f     g3    GHI   
12 g4       s3         101 s3     x         f     g4    JKL   
13 g1       s4          94 s4     y         f     g1    ABC   
14 g2       s4         112 s4     y         f     g2    DEF   
15 g3       s4         108 s4     y         f     g3    GHI   
16 g4       s4          99 s4     y         f     g4    JKL   


What does this mean “SE-tibble abstraction”?

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Tidyomics is an API
We can use our familiar verbs and interact with the native Bioconductor object using standard R/Bioconductor methods.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Still a standard Bioc object


[1] "SummarizedExperiment"
attr(,"package")
[1] "SummarizedExperiment"


[1] 4 4

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
section: We can use familiar dplyr verbs
text:
We can use familiar dplyr verbs

se |> 
  filter(condition == "x")

# A SummarizedExperiment-tibble abstraction: 8 × 8
# Features=4 | Samples=2 | Assays=counts
  .feature .sample counts sample condition sex   id    symbol
  <chr>    <chr>    <int> <chr>  <chr>     <chr> <chr> <chr> 
1 g1       s1          94 s1     x         m     g1    ABC   
2 g2       s1         111 s1     x         m     g2    DEF   
3 g3       s1          83 s1     x         m     g3    GHI   
4 g4       s1         101 s1     x         m     g4    JKL   
5 g1       s3         112 s3     x         f     g1    ABC   
6 g2       s3         103 s3     x         f     g2    DEF   
7 g3       s3         104 s3     x         f     g3    GHI   
8 g4       s3         101 s3     x         f     g4    JKL

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
section: We can use familiar dplyr verbs
text:
We can use familiar dplyr verbs

se_sub <- se |> 
  filter(condition == "x")
colData(se_sub)

DataFrame with 2 rows and 3 columns
        sample   condition         sex
   <character> <character> <character>
s1          s1           x           m
s3          s3           x           f

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Facilitates quick exploration

library(ggplot2)
se |> 
  filter(.feature %in% c("g1","g2")) |> 
  ggplot(aes(condition, counts, color=sex, group=sex)) + 
  geom_point(size=2) + geom_line() +
  facet_wrap(~.feature) + ylim(0,200)

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
section: Efficient operation on SE with plyxp
text: Efficient operation on SE with plyxp

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
section: Efficient operation on SE with plyxp
text:
Efficient operation on SE with plyxp

assay(simple)

  a b c  d
A 1 4 7 10
B 2 5 8 11
C 3 6 9 12

colData(simple)

DataFrame with 4 rows and 1 column
      type
  <factor>
a        1
b        1
c        2
d        2

rowData(simple)

DataFrame with 3 rows and 1 column
     length
  <numeric>
A        10
B        20
C        30

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Specifying `plyxp` methods

library(plyxp)
xp <- simple |> 
  new_plyxp()
xp

# A SummarizedExperiment-tibble Abstraction: 3 × 4
    .features .samples | counts | length | type 
    <chr>     <chr>    |  <int> |  <dbl> | <fct>
  1 A         a        |      1 |     10 | 1    
  2 B         a        |      2 |     20 | 1    
  3 C         a        |      3 |     30 | 1    
  4 A         b        |      4 |     10 | 1    
  5 B         b        |      5 |     20 | 1    
  … …         …               …        …   …    
n-4 B         c        |      8 |     20 | 2    
n-3 C         c        |      9 |     30 | 2    
n-2 A         d        |     10 |     10 | 2    
n-1 B         d        |     11 |     20 | 2    
n   C         d        |     12 |     30 | 2    
# ℹ n = 12

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Mutate with plyxp

xp |> 
  mutate(norm_counts = counts / .rows$length)

# A SummarizedExperiment-tibble Abstraction: 3 × 4
    .features .samples | counts norm_counts | length | type 
    <chr>     <chr>    |  <int>       <dbl> |  <dbl> | <fct>
  1 A         a        |      1        0.1  |     10 | 1    
  2 B         a        |      2        0.1  |     20 | 1    
  3 C         a        |      3        0.1  |     30 | 1    
  4 A         b        |      4        0.4  |     10 | 1    
  5 B         b        |      5        0.25 |     20 | 1    
  … …         …               …          …         …   …    
n-4 B         c        |      8        0.4  |     20 | 2    
n-3 C         c        |      9        0.3  |     30 | 2    
n-2 A         d        |     10        1    |     10 | 2    
n-1 B         d        |     11        0.55 |     20 | 2    
n   C         d        |     12        0.4  |     30 | 2    
# ℹ n = 12

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Grammar for group and summarize

summed <- xp |>
  group_by(cols(type)) |>
  summarize(sum = rowSums(counts))
summed

# A SummarizedExperiment-tibble Abstraction: 3 × 2
# Groups: cols(type)
  .features .samples |   sum | length |  type
  <chr>        <int> | <dbl> |  <dbl> | <int>
1 A                1 |     5 |     10 |     1
2 B                1 |     7 |     20 |     1
3 C                1 |     9 |     30 |     1
4 A                2 |    17 |     10 |     2
5 B                2 |    19 |     20 |     2
6 C                2 |    21 |     30 |     2

assay(summed)

  [,1] [,2]
A    5   17
B    7   19
C    9   21

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Computing on genomic ranges

Translate biological or biomedical questions about the genome into code.
Leverage familiar concepts of filters, joins, grouping, mutation, or summarization.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text: Genomic overlap as a join

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Genomic overlap as a join

library(plyranges)
x

GRanges object with 40 ranges and 1 metadata column:
       seqnames    ranges strand |     score
          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <numeric>
   [1]        1   114-115      * |   4.88780
   [2]        1   129-130      * |   4.40817
   [3]        1   154-155      * |   5.18773
   [4]        1   195-196      * |   5.81901
   [5]        1   200-201      * |   4.14720
   ...      ...       ...    ... .       ...
  [36]        1   898-899      * |   6.55006
  [37]        1   922-923      * |   6.46796
  [38]        1   956-957      * |   4.93079
  [39]        1   957-958      * |   4.34292
  [40]        1   966-967      * |   4.53976
  -------
  seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Genomic overlap as a join

y

GRanges object with 3 ranges and 1 metadata column:
      seqnames    ranges strand |          id
         <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <character>
  [1]        1   101-300      * |           a
  [2]        1   451-650      * |           b
  [3]        1  801-1000      * |           c
  -------
  seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Computing overlap (here inner join)

x |> join_overlap_inner(y)

GRanges object with 30 ranges and 2 metadata columns:
       seqnames    ranges strand |     score          id
          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <numeric> <character>
   [1]        1   114-115      * |   4.88780           a
   [2]        1   129-130      * |   4.40817           a
   [3]        1   154-155      * |   5.18773           a
   [4]        1   195-196      * |   5.81901           a
   [5]        1   200-201      * |   4.14720           a
   ...      ...       ...    ... .       ...         ...
  [26]        1   898-899      * |   6.55006           c
  [27]        1   922-923      * |   6.46796           c
  [28]        1   956-957      * |   4.93079           c
  [29]        1   957-958      * |   4.34292           c
  [30]        1   966-967      * |   4.53976           c
  -------
  seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Convenience functions

# many convenience functions
y |> 
  anchor_5p() |> # 5', 3', start, end, center
  mutate(width=2) |>
  join_nearest(x, distance=TRUE)

GRanges object with 3 ranges and 3 metadata columns:
      seqnames    ranges strand |          id     score  distance
         <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> | <character> <numeric> <integer>
  [1]        1   101-102      * |           a   4.88780        11
  [2]        1   451-452      * |           b   3.99047         1
  [3]        1   801-802      * |           c   6.49877        21
  -------
  seqinfo: 1 sequence from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths

section: Assess overlap significance using a tidy grammar
text:
Assess overlap significance using a tidy grammar
something here

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Defining null genomic range sets

We developed a package nullranges, as a modular tool to assist with making genomic comparisons.
No enrichment analysis but provides null genomic range sets for investigating various hypotheses.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Bootstrapping ranges
Statistical papers from the ENCODE project noted that block bootstrapping genomic data preserves important spatial patterns (Bickel et al. 2010).

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
bootRanges

library(nullranges)
boot <- bootRanges(x, blockLength=10, R=20)
# keep track of bootstrap iteration, gives boot dist'n
boot |>
  join_overlap_inner(y) |>
  group_by(iter, id) |>
  summarize(n_overlaps = n())

DataFrame with 60 rows and 3 columns
     iter          id n_overlaps
    <Rle> <character>  <integer>
1       1           a          4
2       1           b         10
3       1           c          4
4       2           a         11
5       2           b         10
...   ...         ...        ...
56     19           b         18
57     19           c         11
58     20           a         10
59     20           b         15
60     20           c          8

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Matching ranges
Matching on covariates from a large pool allows for more focused hypothesis testing.

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Group and summarize

combined <- bind_ranges(
  focal = xprime,
  matching = matched(m),
  pool = x,
  .id = "origin"
)
# now use the different sets for computation:
combined |> 
  join_overlap_inner(y) |>
  group_by(id, origin) |>
  summarize(ave_score = mean(score))

DataFrame with 9 rows and 3 columns
           id   origin ave_score
  <character>    <Rle> <numeric>
1           a    focal   6.17495
2           a matching   5.54412
3           a     pool   5.00465
4           b    focal   5.79665
5           b matching   6.07625
6           b     pool   5.25055
7           c    focal   6.32536
8           c matching   5.82463
9           c     pool   5.14840

What has been implemented
Put people’s packages names etc.

Matrix-shaped objects (SE, SCE)
Ranges
Interactions
Cytometry
Spatial
more to come…

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Limitations

package code and non-standard evaluation
optimized code, e.g. matrix operations

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
How to contribute

https://github.com/tidyomics, read docs, see open challenges
Motivation: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.09.10.557072v2
tidiness_in_bioc channel in Bioconductor Slack

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:
Outro
Omics data analysis means looking at:

main contributions to variance (e.g. PCA, see plotPCA for bulk and OSCA for sc), also variancePartition
column and row densities (tidySE allows directly plotting geom_density of rows/columns, or geom_violin)
known positive features, feature-level plots (filter to feature, pipe to geom_point etc.)

If you’re interested in more complicated use cases of tidyomics see this online book:

Tidy ranges tutorial

title: Tidyomics: Enabling Tidy Data Analysis for Complex Biological Data
text:

Stefano Mangiola (tidyomics leadership, tidy expression, single cell, spatial)

And tidyomics developers: William Hutchison, Timothy Keyes, Helena Crowell, Jacques Serizay, Charlotte Soneson, Eric Davis, Noriaki Sato, Lambda Moses, Boyd Tarlinton, Abdullah Nahid, Miha Kosmac, Quentin Clayssen, Victor Yuan, Wancen Mu, Ji-Eun Park, Izabela Mamede, Min Hyung Ryu, Pierre-Paul Axisa, Paulina Paiz, Chi-Lam Poon, Ming Tang
